raw_text:
Brazil jobless rate hits new low
 
 Brazil's unemployment rate fell to its lowest level in three years in December, according to the government.
 
 The Brazilian Institute for Geography and Statistics (IBGE) said it fell to 9.6% in December from 10.6% in November and 10.9% in December 2003. IBGE also said that average monthly salaries grew 1.9% in December 2004 from December 2003. However, average monthly wages fell 1.8% in December to 895.4 reais ($332; £179.3) from November. Tuesday's figures represent the first time that the unemployment rate has fallen to a single digit since new measurement rules were introduced in 2001. The unemployment rate has been falling gradually since April 2004 when it reached a peak of 13.1%. The jobless rate average for the whole of 2004 was 11.5%, down from 12.3% in 2003, the IBGE said.
 
 This improvement can be attributed to the country's strong economic growth, with the economy registering growth of 5.2% in 2004, the government said. The economy is expected to grow by about 4% this year. President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva promised to reduce unemployment when he was elected two years ago. Nevertheless, some analysts say that unemployment could increase in the next months. "The data is favourable, but a lot of jobs are temporary for the (Christmas) holiday season, so we may see slightly higher joblessness in January and February," Julio Hegedus, chief economist with Lopes Filho & Associates consultancy in Rio de Janeir, told Reuters news agency. Despite his leftist background, President Lula has pursued a surprisingly conservative economic policy, arguing that in order to meet its social promises, the government needs to first reach a sustained economic growth. The unemployment rate is measured in the six main metropolitan areas of Brazil (Sao Paolo, Rio de Janeiro, Belo Horizonte, Recife, Salvador and Porto Alegre), where most of the population is concentrated.
llama3.2:1b: Brazil's unemployment rate fell to 9.6% in December, down from 10.6% in November and 10.9% in 2003. The average monthly salary grew by 1.9% in December, while wages fell by 1.8%. This is the first time the unemployment rate has fallen to a single digit since new measurement rules were introduced in 2001. The economy registered growth of 5.2% in 2004, which is expected to grow by about 4% this year.
llama3.2:3b: Brazil's unemployment rate fell to 9.6% in December, its lowest level in three years. The economy grew 5.2% in 2004, with average monthly salaries increasing 1.9%. Average monthly wages fell 1.8% to 895.4 reais ($332; £179.3). The unemployment rate has been falling gradually since April 2004 and was down from 12.3% in 2003.
gemma2:2b: Brazil's unemployment rate fell to 9.6% in December, its lowest level in three years. This decline was attributed to strong economic growth. Average monthly salaries also saw slight increases despite a decrease in average wages.  Experts predict some short-term fluctuations before long-term improvements due to temporary holiday jobs. President Lula's conservative economic policies have contributed to this positive trend.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Brazil’s jobless rate fell to its lowest level since 2001. The country's economic growth has been strong with a 5.2% GDP in 2004, according to IBGE figures, and the government is committed to reducing unemployment by 4%. Analysts say that if the jobless rate continues falling, it could increase in January and February.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Brazil's unemployment rate fell to 9.6% in December, marking its lowest level since 2001, though average monthly wages decreased by 1.8%. The improvement can be attributed to strong economic growth and a decrease in jobless rates overall, with jobs expected to increase slightly as the Christmas season ends.
qwen2.5:3b: Brazil's jobless rate hit its lowest level in three years at 9.6% in December, down from 10.6% in November and 10.9% in December 2003. Average monthly salaries increased by 1.9% to 895.4 reais ($332; £179.3) in December from the previous year. The IBGE reported that unemployment has been gradually decreasing since April 2004 and reached an average of 11.5% for the whole of 2004, down from 12.3% in 2003. This improvement is attributed to Brazil's strong economic growth, with GDP growth at 5.2% in 2004. However, some analysts predict a possible rise in unemployment due to temporary jobs for the Christmas season. President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva has pursued a conservative economic policy aimed at sustainable growth to meet social promises. The unemployment rate is measured in six main Brazilian metropolitan areas.

deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Alright, I need to summarize the given text about Brazil's unemployment rate. Let me read through it carefully.

The key points are: Brazil's unemployment rate hit a new low in December, going from 10.9% in 2003 to 9.6%. Also, there was a drop in average monthly salaries but wages saw a slight decrease. The government introduced new measurement rules in 2001, which might affect the data.

I should highlight the significant improvement and who is responsible for it. The main points are: low unemployment rate (new low), economic growth, policy by President Lula, and potential issues with seasonal jobs leading to higher unemployment in January/February.

Now, I'll structure this into a concise summary without any explanations or formatting.
</think>

Brazil's unemployment rate fell to 9.6% in December from 10.6% in November and slightly down from 10.9% in 2003. Average monthly salaries increased by 1.9%, while wages remained a bit lower at 895.4 reais ($332; £179.3). This is the first time the rate has fallen to a single digit since 2001, following new measurement rules. Brazil's strong economic growth of 5.2% and expected 4% growth this year contributed to the decline. Despite these gains, some analysts predict potential increases in unemployment starting in January/February due to seasonal job losses. President Lula has pursued a conservative policy despite his leftist background.
tinyllama:1.1b: Brazil's jobless rate plunged to its lowest level in three years in December, according to the Brazilian Institute for Geography and Statistics (IBGE). The average monthly wages rose by 1.9% in December to reach 895.4 reais ($332; £179.3) from November, marking the first time that the rate has fallen to a single digit since new measurement rules were introduced in 2001. The jobless rate average for the whole of 2004 was 11.5%, down from 12.3% in 2003, while the country's strong economic growth, with growth of 5.2% last year, has been attributed to the economy's expected growth this year. Despite President Luiz Inacio Lua da Silva promising to reduce unemployment in the next months, some analysts suggest that the rate could increase slightly in January and February due to temporary jobs during the Christmas holiday season. The government has pursued a conservative economic policy, arguing that in order to meet its social promises, it needs to first reach sustained economic growth.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The Brazilian jobless rate fell to its lowest level in three years in December, according to the government. The unemployment rate fell from 10.9% in December 2003 to 9.6% in December 2004, a reduction of 1.9%. Average monthly salaries grew by 1.8%, reaching 895.4 reais ($332; £179.3) per month from November's levels. The figures represent the first time since new measurement rules were introduced in 2001 that the unemployment rate has fallen to a single digit. This improvement can be attributed to the country's strong economic growth, with the economy registering growth of 5.2% in 2004. President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva promised to reduce unemployment when he was elected two years ago. Nevertheless, some analysts say that unemployment could increase in the next months.
phi:2.7b: Brazil's jobless rate hit a new low of 9.6% in December 2004, down from 10.6% in November and 10.9% in December 2003. The unemployment rate has been gradually falling since April 2004, reaching its lowest point in three years in December 2004. This can be attributed to the country's strong economic growth with an expected 4% growth this year. However, some analysts suggest that the jobless rate may increase in January and February due to temporary jobs created for the Christmas season. The unemployment rate is measured in six main metropolitan areas of Brazil, where most of the population is concentrated.

The unemployment rate has been falling steadily since April 2004 and reached a peak of 13.1% in July 2004. The government attributed the improvement to strong economic growth, which registered a growth of 5.2% in 2004. However, some analysts predict an increase in unemployment in the next months.

chatgpt-4o-latest: Brazil's unemployment rate fell to 9.6% in December, its lowest in three years, down from 10.6% in November and 10.9% in December 2003, according to IBGE. Average monthly salaries grew 1.9% year-on-year but dropped 1.8% from November. This marks the first time unemployment has fallen to a single digit since new measurement rules in 2001. The jobless rate has been declining since April 2004, when it peaked at 13.1%. The 2004 average unemployment rate was 11.5%, down from 12.3% in 2003, driven by strong economic growth of 5.2%. The economy is expected to grow by 4% in 2005. President Lula, who pledged to reduce unemployment, has followed a conservative economic policy to sustain growth. However, analysts warn that joblessness may rise in early 2005 due to seasonal holiday jobs ending. The unemployment rate is measured in Brazil’s six main metropolitan areas.
stablelm2:1.6b: Brazil's unemployment rate drops to single digit for first time since new measurement rules were introduced in December 2013, at 9.6%. The jobless rate average for the whole of 2014 was 5%, down from 3% in 2013. This improvement is attributed to Brazil's strong economic growth of 5.2% in 2014. Unemployment could potentially increase in January and February due to temporary holiday season jobs, according to some analysts.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Brazil's unemployment rate dropped to 9.6% in December 2004, its lowest level in three years, according to the IBGE. This marks the first time a single-digit unemployment rate has been recorded since new measurement rules were implemented in 2001. The unemployment rate, which peaked at 13.1% in April 2004, averaged 11.5% for 2004, down from 12.3% the previous year. This improvement stems from Brazil's robust economic growth of 5.2% in 2004 and is expected to continue at around 4% this year. Despite President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva's campaign promise to reduce unemployment, some analysts predict a slight increase due to seasonal temporary holiday jobs that could translate to higher unemployment in January and February. President Lula has adhered to a conservative economic policy, emphasizing the need for sustained growth before addressing social promises. The unemployment data is based on Brazil's six major metropolitan areas.
